channel.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
channel.description:
Recently i have found a lot of people asking for ints for people's models.
( Just for the mods, this topic is not in the wrong section, i had a small debate with Taharok about why it should be in this section, as it was moved to client hacking, he then accepted my enquiry to move it back. )
These are just 2 quotes from 2 topics on the first page.
[quote="skittle385"]sweet, any ints?[/quote]
[quote="Da 0wnz"]Kind of glitchy I must say, but it might only just be my ints[/quote]
[b]Well i'll tell you something, it's not the ints, it's your models, ints just specify basically which model id to search for in your models folder, but there is also zooms, rotations and string id's on the inv models, but we don't have to worry about that too much.[/b]
It seems when adding models, people blame it on the ints, because they think they are hard and confusing, but i tell you this, [b]all you gotta do is change a few numbers.[/b]
So i have decided to come up with a small guide on how to understand the 4 types of ints.
[b]Item ints[/b], [b]NPC Ints[/b], [b]Object Ints[/b], and [b]GFX Ints[/b].
So here we go...
[b]Item Ints[/b] (The variables placed in class8.java)
[code]if(i == #####) // Your desired item id (the one you use after ::pickup ##### #) { class8.aStringArray189 = new String[5]; class8.aStringArray189[1] = "Wear"; // String name, this can be changed to wield, or attach, or whatever you want class8.anInt174 = #####; // Drop/Inv Model class8.anInt165 = #####; // Male Wield Model class8.anInt200 = #####; // Female Wield class8.anInt188 = -1; // Male arms/sleeves (Leave as -1 if not used) class8.anInt164 = -1; // Female arms/sleeves (Leave as -1 if not used) class8.anInt181 = 800; // Zoom - Increase to make inv model smaller class8.anInt190 = 540; // Rotate up/down - Increase to rotate upwards class8.anInt198 = 0; // Rotate right/left - Increase to rotate right class8.anInt169 = -1; // Position in inv, increase to move right class8.anInt194 = -1; // Position in inv, increase to move up class8.aString170 = "@@@@@@@@@@@"; // Item Name class8.aByteArray178 = "@@@@@@@@@@".getBytes(); // Item Examine class8.aStringArray168 = null; }[/code]
[b]Notes[/b]
[ul][li]The model id's must correspond to the model numbers that are placed in your models folder.[/li] [li]If there are no sleeve/arms models, for example, with a weapon, then leave the number as just -1 (Or you can just delete the whole of the line)[/li] [li]When renaming models when putting them into your models folder, they must be renamed between [b]8000 - 15000[/b], if not, then your cache may become broken, and simple models such as chickens, may be overwritten by the armadyl godsword special gfx.[/li] [li]The polygon count must be between 1 and about 1500 at the max, or it will just disconnect you[/li][/ul]
___________________________________________________
[b]NPC Ints[/b] (Placed in class5.java)
These can be a little more complicated.
[code] if(i == ###) { // NPC ID aClass30_Sub2_Sub2_60.anInt1406 = anIntArray72[630]; class5.method165(true, aClass30_Sub2_Sub2_60); // Don't need to worry class5.aStringArray66 = new String[5]; class5.aStringArray66[1] = "Attack"; // This string could be changed to anything, for example, in hunting, catch. class5.anIntArray94 = new int[1]; // Number of models the NPC uses, the [1] part class5.anIntArray94[0] = #####; // MODEL ID class5.aString65 = "@@@@@"; // NPC name class5.anInt61 = ######; // Combat level } [/code]
That is for an NPC that only has one model for the whole monster, for example. A Chicken.
If the NPC uses more than one model, for example, a mithril dragon, then it would look more like this.
[code] if(i == ###) { // NPC ID aClass30_Sub2_Sub2_60.anInt1406 = anIntArray72[630]; class5.method165(true, aClass30_Sub2_Sub2_60); // Don't need to worry class5.aStringArray66 = new String[5]; class5.aStringArray66[1] = "Attack"; // This string could be changed to anything, for example, in hunting, catch. class5.anIntArray94 = new int[4]; // Number of models the NPC uses, notice the [4] part class5.anIntArray94[0] = #####; // MODEL ID 1 class5.anIntArray94[1] = #####; // MODEL ID 2 class5.anIntArray94[2] = #####; // MODEL ID 3 class5.anIntArray94[3] = #####; // MODEL ID 4 class5.aString65 = "@@@@@"; // NPC name class5.anInt61 = ######; // Combat level } [/code]
Notice the number on the left side of the model id going up by 1 each time? And when using more models, the number next to "How many models the NPC uses" also has to change.
[b]Notes[/b]
[ul][li]The model id's must correspond to the model numbers that are placed in your models folder.[/li] [li]When renaming models when putting them into your models folder, they must be renamed between [b]8000 - 15000[/b], if not, then your cache may become broken, and simple models such as chickens, may be overwritten by the armadyl godsword special gfx.[/li] [li]The polygon count must be between 1 and about 1500 at the max, or it will just disconnect you[/li][/ul]
___________________________________________________
[b]Object Ints[/b] (Placed in class46.java)
[code]
if(i == ####)// Desired Object id { class46.aString739 = "@@@@@@@@@@@"; //object name class46.aByteArray777 = "@@@@@@@@@@@".getBytes(); //examine class46.anInt744 = 1; class46.anInt761 = 1; class46.anIntArray773 = new int[1]; class46.anIntArray773[0] = #####; // Model id class46.aBoolean778 = true; class46.aBoolean767 = false; class46.aBoolean762 = false; class46.aBoolean769 = false; } [/code]
Sorry i have not labelled the rest, they are not really required anyway, they are just whether they are [b]right clickable[/b], [b]walk throughable[/b], etc.
Please notify me if i need to expand on exactly where to add the code in class46.
[b]Notes[/b]
[ul][li]The model id's must correspond to the model numbers that are placed in your models folder.[/li] [li]When renaming models when putting them into your models folder, they must be renamed between [b]8000 - 15000[/b], if not, then your cache may become broken, and simple models such as chickens, may be overwritten by the armadyl godsword special gfx.[/li] [li]The polygon count must be between 1 and about 1500 at the max, or it will just disconnect you[/li][/ul]
___________________________________________________
[b]GFX Ints[/b] (These are placed in class23)
[code] case ###: // Desired Gfx Id originalDataID = 282; // Makes it so the gfx doesn't move, this is the animation id, change to what you would like it to move like. gfx.anInt405 = @@@@; // Model Id break; [/code]
Please notify me if i need to expand on exactly where to add the code in class23.
[b]Notes[/b]
[ul][li]The model id's must correspond to the model numbers that are placed in your models folder.[/li] [li]When renaming models when putting them into your models folder, they must be renamed between [b]8000 - 15000[/b], if not, then your cache may become broken, and simple models such as chickens, may be overwritten by the armadyl godsword special gfx.[/li] [li]The polygon count must be between 1 and about 1500 at the max, or it will just disconnect you[/li][/ul]
___________________________________________________
Ok, good luck. Hope this helps :)

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

[quote=“i pk 120, post:102, topic:251798”]OMFG I HATE INTS!

OT: Hope this works =_=, I’ll edit this post and tell you the result.

Edit: My Custom item is still a null. IT’S THE INTS FAULT I JUST KNOW IT MAN STOP IT.[/quote]Shut up. You probably didn’t add the item into your client yet by saying “add model #####” or “add models #####”.

Oh, and if you see this CJ, these ints seem to be better:

if(i == #####) // Your desired item id (the one you use after ::pickup ##### #) { class8.aStringArray189 = new String[5]; class8.aStringArray189[1] = "Wear"; // String name, this can be changed to wield, or attach, or whatever you want class8.anInt174 = #####; // Drop/Inv Model class8.anInt165 = #####; // Male Wield Model class8.anInt200 = #####; // Female Wield class8.anInt188 = -1; // Male arms/sleeves (Leave as -1 if not used) class8.anInt164 = -1; // Female arms/sleeves (Leave as -1 if not used) class8.anInt181 = 800; // Zoom - Increase to make inv model smaller class8.anInt190 = 540; // Rotate up/down - Increase to rotate upwards class8.anInt198 = 0; // Rotate right/left - Increase to rotate right class8.anInt169 = -1; // Position in inv, increase to move right class8.anInt194 = -1; // Position in inv, increase to move up class8.aString170 = "@@@@@@@@@@@"; // Item Name class8.aByteArray178 = "@@@@@@@@@@".getBytes(); // Item Examine class8.aStringArray168 = null; }

They have better rotations, and make the inventory model look like the camera is looking straight down at the drop model.

Read full topic

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

[quote=“Ebowne24, post:91, topic:251798”]Do I have to make new model for every new number of stack-able items?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: December 19, 2009, 11:38:00 pm[/size][hr][quote author=T3arful link=topic=332426.msg3066694#msg3066694 date=1261268312]
If you want custom noted items;

if(i == 8003) {
class8.aStringArray189 = null; //Don't change this
class8.anInt163 = 799; //Don't change this.
class8.anInt179 = 8002; //ID of the item that you're going to turn into a note.
}

Don’t use what CJ posted, it cancels out all the rotations, and it’s wrong to begin with.
[/quote]
I did this, and I can spawn the item, but when I try and pull the unnoted item out of the bank as a note, it doesn’t exactly work.
Do I have to add something extra?[/quote]
Yes to your first question.
And to your second question; noting is done server side as well, have a look in your Item class.

Read full topic

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

I use a switch for items. But yes change the case # to if(i == #
If the items are stackable you do add the same code over and over, all you need to change is the model ID/anInt174.

As to your first question, yes you do add it as a new thing.
Here’s a better example; say you wanted to have an Armadyl Godsword noted, and it’s ID was 11694 you would add

if(i == 11695) {
class8.aStringArray189 = null; //Don't change this
class8.anInt163 = 799; //Don't change this.
class8.anInt179 = 11694; //ID of the item that you're going to turn into a note.
}

The noted version of the item’s ID would then be 11695. No editing of the Armadyl Godswords ints is needed.

Read full topic
item.source: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @Ebowne24 Ebowne24
item.description:
@Ebowne24 wrote:

[quote=“T3arful, post:86, topic:251798”]If you want custom noted items;

if(i == 8003) {
class8.aStringArray189 = null; //Don't change this
class8.anInt163 = 799; //Don't change this.
class8.anInt179 = 8002; //ID of the item that you're going to turn into a note.
}

Don’t use what CJ posted, it cancels out all the rotations, and it’s wrong to begin with.[/quote]
So do I add this as a completely different thing in my class8? Or just add it to the current item? And just make a new ID for it?

[quote=“T3arful, post:88, topic:251798”]Here’s how to do stackable items also.

		class8.anIntArray201[0] = 2;
		class8.anIntArray193[0] = 9146;
		class8.anIntArray201[1] = 3;
		class8.anIntArray193[1] = 9147;
		class8.anIntArray201[2] = 4;
		class8.anIntArray193[2] = 9148;
		class8.anIntArray201[3] = 5;
		class8.anIntArray193[3] = 9149;

The anIntArray193 is the item id
The anIntArray201 is the amount of the item.
Eg

		class8.anIntArray201[0] = 2;
		class8.anIntArray193[0] = 9146;

If the arrow has 2 arrows it will display the model + rotations etc you have for item id 9146

	case 9146:
		class8.anIntArray160 = new int[5];
		class8.anIntArray156 = new int[5];
		class8.anIntArray160[0] = -22303;
		class8.anIntArray156[0] = 17971;
		class8.anIntArray160[1] = -22303;
		class8.anIntArray156[1] = 5537;
		class8.anIntArray160[2] = -22050;
		class8.anIntArray156[2] = 5532;
		class8.anIntArray160[3] = -22054;
		class8.anIntArray156[3] = 5656;
		class8.anIntArray160[4] = -21674;
		class8.anIntArray156[4] = 5652;
		class8.anInt174 = 16863;
		class8.anInt165 = -1;
		class8.anInt188 = -1;
		class8.anInt202 = 0;
		class8.aBoolean176 = true;
		class8.anInt198 = 117;
		class8.anInt181 = 720;
		class8.anInt155 = 1;
		class8.anInt200 = -1;
		class8.anInt164 = -1;
		class8.anInt169 = 3;
		class8.anInt204 = 0;
		class8.anInt194 = 5;
		class8.anInt179 = -1;
		class8.anInt190 = 477;
	break;

Which displays model ID

class8.anInt174 = 16863;

Thus getting your stackables.

Here’s a complete example


And the code would be

case 8851: class8.aString170 = "Warrior guild token"; class8.aStringArray189 = new String[5]; class8.aStringArray189[4] = "Drop"; class8.anInt174 = 15343; class8.anIntArray201 = new int[10]; class8.anIntArray193 = new int[10]; class8.anIntArray201[0] = 2; class8.anIntArray193[0] = 8852; class8.anIntArray201[1] = 3; class8.anIntArray193[1] = 8853; class8.anIntArray201[2] = 4; class8.anIntArray193[2] = 8854; class8.anIntArray201[3] = 5; class8.anIntArray193[3] = 8855; class8.anInt165 = -1; class8.anInt188 = -1; class8.anInt202 = 0; class8.aBoolean176 = true; class8.anInt198 = 180; class8.anInt181 = 724; class8.anInt155 = 1; class8.anInt200 = -1; class8.anInt164 = -1; class8.anInt169 = 9; class8.anInt204 = 0; class8.anInt194 = -100; class8.anInt179 = -1; class8.anInt190 = 238; class8.aByteArray178 = "It's a Warrior guild token.".getBytes(); break; case 8852: class8.anInt174 = 15344; class8.anInt165 = -1; class8.anInt188 = -1; class8.anInt202 = 0; class8.aBoolean176 = true; class8.anInt198 = 180; class8.anInt181 = 724; class8.anInt155 = 1; class8.anInt200 = -1; class8.anInt164 = -1; class8.anInt169 = 9; class8.anInt204 = 0; class8.anInt194 = -100; class8.anInt179 = -1; class8.anInt190 = 238; break; case 8853: class8.anInt174 = 15345; class8.anInt165 = -1; class8.anInt188 = -1; class8.anInt202 = 0; class8.aBoolean176 = true; class8.anInt198 = 180; class8.anInt181 = 724; class8.anInt155 = 1; class8.anInt200 = -1; class8.anInt164 = -1; class8.anInt169 = 9; class8.anInt204 = 0; class8.anInt194 = -100; class8.anInt179 = -1; class8.anInt190 = 238; break; case 8854: class8.anInt174 = 15346; class8.anInt165 = -1; class8.anInt188 = -1; class8.anInt202 = 0; class8.aBoolean176 = true; class8.anInt198 = 180; class8.anInt181 = 724; class8.anInt155 = 1; class8.anInt200 = -1; class8.anInt164 = -1; class8.anInt169 = 9; class8.anInt204 = 0; class8.anInt194 = -100; class8.anInt179 = -1; class8.anInt190 = 238; break; case 8855: class8.anInt174 = 15347; class8.anInt165 = -1; class8.anInt188 = -1; class8.anInt202 = 0; class8.aBoolean176 = true; class8.anInt198 = 180; class8.anInt181 = 724; class8.anInt155 = 1; class8.anInt200 = -1; class8.anInt164 = -1; class8.anInt169 = 9; class8.anInt204 = 0; class8.anInt194 = -100; class8.anInt179 = -1; class8.anInt190 = 238; break; [/quote]
For your “case ####” part, would I just put:

if(i == ####) {

And do I have to add the same code for every different #? I’m kind of confused at that part, sorry.

Read full topic
item.source: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

Here’s how to do stackable items also.

		class8.anIntArray201[0] = 2;
		class8.anIntArray193[0] = 9146;
		class8.anIntArray201[1] = 3;
		class8.anIntArray193[1] = 9147;
		class8.anIntArray201[2] = 4;
		class8.anIntArray193[2] = 9148;
		class8.anIntArray201[3] = 5;
		class8.anIntArray193[3] = 9149;

The anIntArray193 is the item id
The anIntArray201 is the amount of the item.
Eg

		class8.anIntArray201[0] = 2;
		class8.anIntArray193[0] = 9146;

If the arrow has 2 arrows it will display the model + rotations etc you have for item id 9146

	case 9146:
		class8.anIntArray160 = new int[5];
		class8.anIntArray156 = new int[5];
		class8.anIntArray160[0] = -22303;
		class8.anIntArray156[0] = 17971;
		class8.anIntArray160[1] = -22303;
		class8.anIntArray156[1] = 5537;
		class8.anIntArray160[2] = -22050;
		class8.anIntArray156[2] = 5532;
		class8.anIntArray160[3] = -22054;
		class8.anIntArray156[3] = 5656;
		class8.anIntArray160[4] = -21674;
		class8.anIntArray156[4] = 5652;
		class8.anInt174 = 16863;
		class8.anInt165 = -1;
		class8.anInt188 = -1;
		class8.anInt202 = 0;
		class8.aBoolean176 = true;
		class8.anInt198 = 117;
		class8.anInt181 = 720;
		class8.anInt155 = 1;
		class8.anInt200 = -1;
		class8.anInt164 = -1;
		class8.anInt169 = 3;
		class8.anInt204 = 0;
		class8.anInt194 = 5;
		class8.anInt179 = -1;
		class8.anInt190 = 477;
	break;

Which displays model ID

class8.anInt174 = 16863;

Thus getting your stackables.

Here’s a complete example


And the code would be

	case 8851:
		class8.aString170 = "Warrior guild token";
		class8.aStringArray189 = new String[5];
		class8.aStringArray189[4] = "Drop";
		class8.anInt174 = 15343;
		class8.anIntArray201 = new int[10];

		class8.anInt204 = 0;
		class8.anInt194 = -100;
		class8.anInt179 = -1;
		class8.anInt190 = 238;
		class8.aByteArray178 = "It's a Warrior guild token.".getBytes();
	break;
	case 8852:
		class8.anInt174 = 15344;
		class8.anInt165 = -1;
		class8.anInt188 = -1;
		class8.anInt202 = 0;

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Uhh no.
Actually, I don’t have a clue how it works, to be honest.

But I do know that.

class8.anInt174 = 2834;

Is a dragon longsword.

And:

class8.anInt174 = 2429;

Is a note.
So.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: 20-12-2009, 00:24:27[/size][hr]What he said, ahah. ^^

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @T3arful T3arful
item.description:
@T3arful wrote:

If you want custom noted items;

if(i == 8003) {
class8.aStringArray189 = null; //Don't change this
class8.anInt163 = 799; //Don't change this.
class8.anInt179 = 8002; //ID of the item that you're going to turn into a note.
}

Don’t use what CJ posted, it cancels out all the rotations, and it’s wrong to begin with.

Read full topic

item.title: How To Make Ints. Stop blaming your ints, it's your models
item.dc:creator: @Ebowne24 Ebowne24
item.description:
@Ebowne24 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:80, topic:251798”]…
I’ll just post an example.
If you downloaded an itemdump then maybe you would understand.

This is the dragon longsword, as the item, not noted.

	if(i == 1305) //ID
		{
			class8.aStringArray189 = new String[5];
			class8.aStringArray189[1] = "Wear";
			class8.aString170 = "Dragon longsword"; //Name
			class8.aByteArray178 = "Your Description Here".getBytes(); //Description
			class8.anInt174 = 2834;
			class8.anInt181 = 1570;
			class8.anInt190 = 400;
			class8.anInt198 = 360;
			class8.anInt204 = 0;
			class8.anInt169 = 0;
			class8.anInt194 = -5;
			class8.anInt165 = 564;
			class8.anInt200 = 564;
			class8.anInt188 = -1;
			class8.anInt164 = -1;
			class8.anInt175 = -1;
			class8.anInt197 = -1;
		}

And this is the dragon longsword in a note.

	if(i == 1306) //ID
		{
			class8.aStringArray189 = new String[5];
			class8.aStringArray189[1] = "Wear";
			class8.aString170 = "Dragon longsword"; //Name
			class8.aByteArray178 = "Your Description Here".getBytes(); //Description
			class8.anInt174 = 2429;
			class8.anInt181 = 760;
			class8.anInt190 = 552;
			class8.anInt198 = 28;
			class8.anInt204 = 0;
			class8.anInt169 = 0;
			class8.anInt194 = 2;
			class8.anInt165 = -1;
			class8.anInt200 = -1;
			class8.anInt188 = -1;
			class8.anInt164 = -1;
			class8.anInt175 = -1;
			class8.anInt197 = -1;
		}

See the only difference is the variables I already posted.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: 19-12-2009, 10:08:58[/size][hr]owait. shit.

Just realised the drop model changed too.
My bad.[/quote]
I do have an item dump. That’s why I asked.
So does that mean you have to create a blank note with let’s say… D-long on it…?
